docs.abstract: The jury convicted Mr. Chauvin of second- and third-degree murder, as well as manslaughter. He faces up to 40 years in prison but is likely to be sentenced to far less time, based on state guidelines.
docs.snippet: The jury convicted Mr. Chauvin of second- and third-degree murder, as well as manslaughter. He faces up to 40 years in prison but is likely to be sentenced to far less time, based on state guidelines.
docs.lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin was found guilty of two counts of murder on Tuesday in the death of George Floyd, whose final breaths last May under the knee of Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, were captured on video, setting off months of protests against the police abuse of Black people.

headline.main: Derek Chauvin is found guilty of murdering George Floyd.

byline.original: By Tim Arango, Shaila Dewan, John Eligon and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

docs.abstract: The presentation of evidence concluded on Thursday without testimony from Mr. Chauvin himself.
docs.snippet: The presentation of evidence concluded on Thursday without testimony from Mr. Chauvin himself.
docs.lead_paragraph: The presentation of evidence in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder in the death of George Floyd, concluded on Thursday without testimony from Mr. Chauvin himself.

headline.main: Takeaways from Derek Chauvin’s defense case.

docs.abstract: Mr. Biden said he expressed his support and sympathy during the call and told reporters that he was praying for “the right verdict” in the Derek Chauvin trial.
docs.snippet: Mr. Biden said he expressed his support and sympathy during the call and told reporters that he was praying for “the right verdict” in the Derek Chauvin trial.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Biden called the family of George Floyd on Monday to express his support and sympathy, telling reporters on Tuesday that the evidence against the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin was “overwhelming” and that he was praying for the “right verdict.” Hours later, a jury found Mr. Chauvin guilty of second-degree murder, third-degree murder and manslaughter.

headline.main: President Biden calls George Floyd’s family and says evidence for a guilty verdict is ‘overwhelming.’

docs.abstract: Dr. Baker determined during his autopsy of George Floyd that he died from “cardiopulmonary arrest” and declared his death a homicide.
docs.snippet: Dr. Baker determined during his autopsy of George Floyd that he died from “cardiopulmonary arrest” and declared his death a homicide.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Andrew Baker, the Hennepin County medical examiner,  testified on Friday at former officer Derek Chauvin’s trial that he found bruises on George Floyd’s body during the initial autopsy.

headline.main: Dr. Andrew Baker, Hennepin County’s chief medical examiner, takes the stand.

docs.abstract: If the industry won’t change on principle, it can at least change for the money. Reform would enrich people of color, and everyone else.
docs.snippet: If the industry won’t change on principle, it can at least change for the money. Reform would enrich people of color, and everyone else.
docs.lead_paragraph: Days after a Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin, suffocated George Floyd and the video went viral, I watched my social media feed fill with blackout tiles and corporate publicity statements. They poured in from every industry, proclaiming solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement. Hollywood — where I have worked for almost two decades — was no exception.

headline.main: Hollywood’s Anti-Black Bias Costs It $10 Billion a Year
headline.print_headline: Hollywood Bias Comes at a Hefty Price

docs.abstract: An analysis of body camera footage shows that one officer appeared to keep his knee on the upper right side of Mr. Gonzalez’s back for 2 minutes 50 seconds.
docs.snippet: An analysis of body camera footage shows that one officer appeared to keep his knee on the upper right side of Mr. Gonzalez’s back for 2 minutes 50 seconds.
docs.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — One day before a Minneapolis jury convicted a former officer of murdering George Floyd, police officers answering a complaint about someone loitering in a park in the Bay Area suburb of Alameda pinned Mario Arenales Gonzalez to the ground facedown, using their knees, elbows and forearms.

headline.main: An Alameda Police Officer Used His Knee to Pin Down Mario Gonzalez
headline.print_headline: In Video, California Officer Pins Down Man, Who Dies

byline.original: By Shawn Hubler and Evan Hill

docs.abstract: The first medical expert called by Derek Chauvin’s defense team said George Floyd died after a combination of factors — including pre-existing heart conditions, drug use and exposure to vehicle exhaust from the police cruiser — caused his death. He faced difficult cross-examination.
docs.snippet: The first medical expert called by Derek Chauvin’s defense team said George Floyd died after a combination of factors — including pre-existing heart conditions, drug use and exposure to vehicle exhaust from the police cruiser — caused his death. H...
docs.lead_paragraph: The first medical expert witness called by Derek Chauvin’s defense team faced difficult cross-examination on Wednesday after he testified that George Floyd died from sudden cardiac arrhythmia, rather than a deprivation of oxygen caused by Mr. Chauvin.

headline.main: Takeaways from Day 13 of the Derek Chauvin trial.

docs.abstract: Jurors heard from two key witnesses, including the chief of police. He said Mr. Chauvin “absolutely” violated department policies.
docs.snippet: Jurors heard from two key witnesses, including the chief of police. He said Mr. Chauvin “absolutely” violated department policies.
docs.lead_paragraph: The sixth day of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd, brought two key witnesses to the stand: the doctor who spent 30 minutes trying to save Mr. Floyd’s life before pronouncing him dead, and the chief of the Minneapolis Police Department.

headline.main: Here are the takeaways from Day 6 of the Derek Chauvin trial.

headline.main: Michigan, George Floyd, Baseball: Your Thursday Evening Briefing

byline.original: By Will Dudding and Sarah Hughes

docs.abstract: He has been placed in an isolated wing of Minnesota’s only maximum-security prison because of fears for his safety.
docs.snippet: He has been placed in an isolated wing of Minnesota’s only maximum-security prison because of fears for his safety.
docs.lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin is being held in solitary confinement for 23 hours a day in Minnesota’s only maximum-security prison after he was convicted of murdering George Floyd and led out of a courtroom in handcuffs, according to authorities.

headline.main: Derek Chauvin is being held in solitary confinement for 23 hours a day.

byline.original: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Tim Arango
